title: Welcome to My Data Science Portfolio
text:
Welcome to my data science portfolio! This site shows my journey learning data science and analytics. Here you’ll find projects that demonstrate what I’ve learned and discovered.


This portfolio shows my work learning data science. Each project includes:

My code with documentation
Visualizations I created
What I learned and discovered

I built this site using Quarto and host it on GitHub Pages.




Programming: Python, Pandas for data analysis
Visualization: Creating charts with Matplotlib and Seaborn
Data Collection: Getting data from files, websites, and APIs
Analysis: Finding patterns and answering questions with data







Learn how I explore datasets to find interesting patterns and answer questions.



See how I gather data from different sources and prepare it for analysis.



See how I tackle a data science project beginning to end.



Thanks for visiting! Feel free to explore my projects and see what I’m learning.

title: About Me
text: Profile Picture

title: About Me
text:
Background
I am a driven, people focused individual studying at Brigham Young university. I am in my third year, and I am studying Statistics with an emphasis in Data Science. I was first inspired to do this by my love for communication and business as well as my love for math and problem solving. My goal is to help people make informed, data-driven decisions to help people and grow businesses. I am currently doing research in the Marriott Business School learning about the sociological effect of AI adoption in the workplace.

title: About Me
text:
Education

Statistics - Brigham Young University, 2027
Relevant Coursework: Statistics, Data Analysis, Programming, Information Systems, and Business

title: About Me
text:
Experience

Research Assistant — Brigham Young University, Marriott School of Business (Strategic Management)
Provo, UT · Apr 2025 – Present

Proofread statistical components of curriculum materials and academic research articles

Migrated a large-scale database from Snowflake to a Linux-based university supercomputer

Analyzed cooperative research survey data using Multinomial and Ordinal Logistic Regression to generate insights on employee perceptions of AI adoption

Computer Programmer (Front-End) — Brigham Young University, Marriott School of Business (ILABZ)
Provo, UT · Mar 2024 – Apr 2025

Built React components using TypeScript as part of a 7-member development team

Developed and maintained five learning-oriented web applications focused on stock markets and international trade

Social Media Specialist — North Carolina Raleigh Mission
Raleigh, NC · Jan 2022 – Jun 2022

Managed monthly social media marketing campaigns using Meta Business Suite

Increased monthly audience reach while maintaining the existing budget

title: About Me
text:
Skills & Interests

Technical Skills

Programming: Python, R
Data Analysis: Pandas, NumPy
Visualization: Matplotlib, Seaborn
Machine Learning: Scikit-learn
Tools: Jupyter Notebooks, Git/GitHub -Quarto: For report writing and presenting visuals
Excel: Experienced in built-in methods as well as VBA (Openpyxl for python integration)



Areas of Interest

I am interested in financial analytics especially the interaction between the price of natural resources with the stock prices of companies that buy them
I am curious about neural networks and complex machine learning techniques



Hobbies

I love backpacking and hiking
In my free time I enjoy reading and playing sports
I ski and love the winter

title: About Me
text:
Goals
I aim to use data science techniques to allow myself to broaden the scope of my questions. I plan to develop skills that enable me to analyze complex datasets and derive meaningful insights. I hope to utilize these skills in the long term to make impactful contributions in my field and to have the skills to answer my own questions using data.

title: Apply Function VS Vectorized Operations
text:
In Class I have been learning about how to utilize Pandas in my data cleaning and analysis. One of the earliest functions we learned is the .apply() function. This is a super useful function that we can use to make changes to all of our rows in one call.
The downside is, it isn’t always the most efficient. This often wont make a huge difference but if we are working with large data sets, it can cut your run time down by a lot.
In this article, I hope to explain:

How does .apply() work?
When should we use it?
What is the alternative?

Having an understanding of apply() and its shortcomings will help you spend less time waiting on your computer and make you a better Data Scientist




The .apply() function takes another function and applies it to each row or column in a Series or DataFrame.
If it sounds like a loop, that’s because it kind of is one.

.apply() executes Python code row-by-row.

This is the main shortcoming, rather than doing things all at once, its going through, one at a time and this takes time while simultaneously not allowing your computer to work as hard as it could using other methods.This is why the difference is much more noticeable on larger datasets.




Code
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({
    "score": [72, 88, 95, 60, 83]
})

def pass_fail(x):
    return "Pass" if x >= 70 else "Fail"

df["result"] = df["score"].apply(pass_fail)
df









score
result




0
72
Pass


1
88
Pass


2
95
Pass


3
60
Fail


4
83
Pass







This is a great use for apply(), it keeps the code intuitive and since it isn’t very large, we dont even notice the extra time it takes.





.apply() makes the most sense when:

When your logic is complex and hard to vectorize
You have conditional transformations
You are in the EDA phase of your analysis
Your dataset is small enough that you aren’t worried about how long it takes





Code
def categorize(score):
    if score >= 90:
        return "A"
    elif score >= 80:
        return "B"
    elif score >= 70:
        return "C"
    else:
        return "Below C"

df["grade"] = df["score"].apply(categorize)
df









score
result
grade




0
72
Pass
C


1
88
Pass
B


2
95
Pass
A


3
60
Fail
Below C


4
83
Pass
B







Similarly to the previous example, this helps the code to be easy to read and understand.





The biggest issue is size.
.apply() as mentioned before works almost like a loop, meaning it performs the operations over and over where as other methods can do it all at once. It still does it very quickly so unless you’re dealing with hundreds of rows it probably wont be a problem but sometimes we are working with millions of rows and that can have a huge difference.
An example of .apply() not being ideal is finding a mean:
\[
\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i
\]
Being able to write it as a simple formula is a big hint that alternative options will be feasible and doing something like this in a loop will take forever. So what are your options?




Bringing us back to Linear algebra and using vectors can help us do some of our computations way more efficiently.
You may be thinking that this is great for numbers but we can also use it with boolean data.




Code
df["result_vectorized"] = df["score"] >= 70
df









score
result
grade
result_vectorized




0
72
Pass
C
True


1
88
Pass
B
True


2
95
Pass
A
True


3
60
Fail
Below C
False


4
83
Pass
B
True







This adds a new column to our dataframe which we can compare to our earlier results, this time it returns True or False which is a little bit less readable but often we would want it that way anyway. Another limitation is that our grade column is going to be much harder to replicate. As you can see by the code though, once you’re familiar with how it works, its more concise and easier to read.
The reason this is so much faster is because it converts the columns into vectors and does everything all at once rather than every row individually.
Since optimization can be really important, Pandas has published official documentation to improve performance. Link Here.








Image comparing loops (Apply function) vs vectorized logic


Figure: Vectorized operations operate on entire arrays at once, rather than looping through rows individually.




Before using the .apply() function:

Is this logic simple?
Is there a built-in Pandas function for this?
Would a Boolean response work?

If you answer yes to any of these, consider avoiding .apply()




.apply() is great and extremely useful in many ways but it isn’t the best tool for every job.
Steps to take:

Utilize built-in Pandas methods whenever possible

Try Vectorized operations
Use .apply() for complex custom transformations

Even if you’re currently working with smaller data where efficiency isn’t a huge priority, consider practicing more efficient methods to build those skills and to be ready for larger datasets.
